The facts, as they lay before us, were few and barren, but my mind, well stocked with the knowledge of the world and its ways, was able to see beyond the obvious. The telegram, the hurried departure, the cryptic message left behind – all pointed to a plan, a scheme so audacious that it could only be the work of Moriarty. Moriarty, the Napoleon of crime, whose intellect was a match for even the keenest of detectives. Yet, he had made a mistake, a small but crucial oversight. It was this that had allowed us to unravel the threads of his latest nefarious plot. The more I pondered, the clearer it became. Moriarty was not merely planning a crime; he was setting the stage for a grand demonstration of his power, a showcase of his ability to outwit the law. And the target of his machinations was none other than the British Crown itself. The King was to be assassinated during his upcoming visit to London, a move that would plunge the nation into chaos and elevate Moriarty to a position of unparalleled influence. But Moriarty had underestimated the tenacity of Sherlock Holmes and the acuity of his trusted companion, Dr. Watson. With the clues we had gathered, we were on the brink of foiling his plans and saving the monarchy from disaster. The game was afoot, and this time, the stakes were higher than ever before.

La investigación no siempre sigue un camino directo; a veces, requiere que se detengan, miren alrededor y escuchen con atención. En el mundo de Holmes, incluso la más mínima de las diferencias puede ser el catalizador de una revelación monumental. Por lo tanto, aunque Watson se arrepienta de no haber pensado más, cada experiencia es una oportunidad para crecer y mejorar. The man shouted after me, but I heeded him not. The streets were fortunately clear, and I made my way rapidly towards the Strand. Once there, I knew I could lose myself among the throngs of people and the labyrinth of streets. The adventure was exhilarating, and I couldn't help but feel a thrill at the successful execution of my impromptu plan. The cab rattled along, and I allowed myself a moment of satisfaction before considering my next move. The purse was secure, but now I needed to decide where to take it. A place where it could be safely exchanged without drawing undue attention. The thought of returning it to its rightful owner crossed my mind, but the thrill of the chase and the promise of reward were too enticing. I decided to seek out a discreet pawnbroker, someone who wouldn't ask too many questions and would pay a fair price for such a valuable item. As I approached the heart of the city, my mind raced with possibilities, each more daring than the last. This was more than just a simple theft; it was a test of wits and daring, and I was determined to pass with flying colors. The city lights began to twinkle as the evening deepened, and with them, my options expanded. I steered the cab towards a part of London less frequented by the police, a place where the shadows were long and the secrets deep. Here, I could blend in, another faceless figure in a city that thrived on anonymity. The purse, a symbol of wealth and power, now rested in my possession, its true owner unaware of the turn of fate that had befallen it. As I navigated the cab through the winding streets, I felt a sense of triumph. This was more than just a successful theft; it was a testament to my cunning and resourcefulness. The night was young, and the possibilities endless. I was ready for whatever came next.

His room is a chaos of photographic plates, half-developed films, and dusty tomes. He spends hours in his darkroom, fiddling with chemicals and machinery, trying to capture the perfect image. It's a wonder he hasn't blown himself up with all those volatile substances. And when he's not in his darkroom, he's buried in some ancient text, deciphering languages long dead or poring over scientific treatises that would baffle most. His mind is as restless as his hands; he can't seem to settle on one pursuit for long. Yet, despite his eccentricities, there's something endearing about his passion. It's as if he's chasing after the ephemeral, trying to pin down moments in time that slip away like smoke. His faults, though they may be many, are woven into the very fabric of his character, making him as complex and intriguing as the subjects of his photographs.”

en_first_half: “‘Why, what is it, then?’ I asked. You see, Mr. Holmes, I am a very stay-at-home man, and as my business came to me instead of my having to go to it, I was
en_second_half: often weeks on end without putting my foot over the door-mat. In that way I didn’t know much of what was going on outside, and I was always glad of a bit of news.
en_results_raw: “‘Why, what is it, then?’ I asked. You see, Mr. Holmes, I am a very stay-at-home man, and as my business came to me instead of my having to go to it, I was not in the habit of wandering about the streets at night. However, my wife, who is a very energetic person, took a fancy to this young fellow, and persuaded me into letting him lodge with us. I did not see much of him, for he was out a good deal, but what I did see I liked well enough. He gave me a written reference, you see, all in order. It was from his last employer, who spoke of him as an excellent lad, quiet, honest, willing, and steady. That was how he struck me, too, until this business occurred. I was away when it happened, but I heard all about it next day. It seems that he had been out in the evening, and came back in the early hours of the morning. He went straight to his room, and his wife, who was a light sleeper, was awakened by his getting into bed. She was a little cross, according to her way, and asked him where he had been to at that time of night. He answered her shortly that it was nobody’s business, at which she was more angry than ever. She would have it, however, and began to question him, but he repulsed her, and at last, in her anger, she struck at him with a candlestick. That was his opportunity, for he closed with her, and it was only when her screams brought the servants to the room that he ceased his violence. She was badly hurt, poor thing, and there were marks upon her throat which the doctors said were caused by fingers, but no actual injury. He was arrested, of course, and confessed everything. He said that the temptation to throttle her had been more than he could resist. He was charged with attempted murder, but as she was not actually hurt in the end, the case against him was not very strong, and he would most likely have been acquitted had he not—well, had he not taken his own life in prison. That, Mr. Holmes, is the whole story, and a most painful one I find it, for I begin to think that I know this young man better than I did, and that there was another side to him of which I was never aware.”

"I suspect, my dear Watson, that this telegram heralds the beginning of an adventure far more peculiar and intriguing than our usual pursuits. The timing is simply too uncanny to be mere chance." He picked up his magnifying glass, already lost in thought about the potential connections and clues hidden within the brief message. "Let us delve into this matter with the same vigor we reserve for our criminal investigations. After all, the line between the extraordinary and the mundane is often thinner than one might expect." With that, Holmes strode towards his desk, ready to unravel the mystery that had so humorously interrupted their plans.

en_first_half: “I was staggered, sir. I did not know what to do. Then I called at the offices round, but none of them seemed to know anything about it. Finally, I went to the landlord, who is an accountant living on the ground floor, and
en_second_half: I asked him if he could tell me what had become of the Red-headed League. He said that he had never heard of any such body. Then I asked him who Mr. Duncan Ross was. He answered that the name was new to him.

The absence of any trace of the painting, despite its size and prominence, was unsettling. I decided to heed the landlord's advice and visited the police station the next morning. The officers were initially skeptical, perhaps accustomed to dealing with misplaced items rather than outright disappearances. However, they took down my statement and promised to look into it. Over the following days, I was contacted by Detective Harris, a seasoned investigator with a reputation for solving the most perplexing cases. He informed me that they had found no leads yet but were expanding their search. The investigation involved interviewing previous tenants, checking surveillance footage from the neighborhood, and even reaching out to art dealers and collectors known for their interest in such works. Despite the efforts, weeks passed without any breakthrough. The absence of the painting cast a shadow over the apartment, and I found myself constantly retracing my steps, trying to recall any detail I might have missed. The landlord, though supportive, seemed increasingly uneasy, as if the mystery was weighing on him too. It was during one of these reflective moments that I remembered a peculiar detail: the day before the painting vanished, I had received an anonymous letter in the mail. It contained no message, just a small, hand-drawn symbol that I couldn't quite place. Could this be a clue? I took the letter to the police, who promised to have it analyzed by their forensics team. The wait for answers was agonizing, each day stretching into the next with no resolution in sight. The painting, once a source of joy and inspiration, had become a symbol of an unsolved mystery that seemed to deepen with every passing hour.

"Well, as I was saying, the peculiar thing about the case was the absence of any tangible evidence," I began, hoping to catch a flicker of interest in his eyes. "The victim, a wealthy businessman named Sir Reginald Thornton, was found dead in his study, yet there was no sign of forced entry, no struggle, and no weapon. It was as if he had simply vanished into thin air." Sherlock leaned forward slightly, his gaze fixed on me, signaling his rapt attention. "And the police?" he interjected, his voice low and intense. "What was their conclusion?" I hesitated, knowing that Sherlock's keen intellect would quickly dissect any flawed reasoning. "They're... stumped," I admitted. "The coroner ruled it a natural death, but the family and some of Thornton's business associates are convinced it was foul play. They've hired me to uncover the truth." Sherlock nodded thoughtfully, his mind already racing through the possibilities. "Fascinating," he murmured. "A death without a cause, a mystery wrapped in enigma. This could be a most intriguing case." His words were a balm to my frayed nerves; finally, I felt I had the right man to unravel this perplexing puzzle.

The fireplace, with its cold, blackened bricks, seemed to hold no secrets. The mantelpiece was cluttered with various knick-knacks and photographs, none of which appeared out of the ordinary. The bookshelves were lined with volumes on a wide array of subjects, from natural history to the arcane. Holmes ran his fingers over the spines, noting the wear and tear on some, indicating frequent consultation. His eyes then fell upon a dusty globe, slightly askew on the corner of the desk. He approached it, giving it a gentle spin, watching as the continents blurred into a mosaic of colors. There was something about the globe that piqued his interest, a detail that seemed out of place. He leaned in closer, his keen eyes scanning the surface for any irregularities. It was then he noticed a small, almost imperceptible, indentation near the equator. It was a clue, a breadcrumb left by someone who thought themselves clever. Holmes smiled faintly, his mind already racing with possibilities. This indentation could lead him to the heart of the mystery, a puzzle waiting to be solved. With a sense of renewed purpose, he tucked the revolver back into his coat and began to examine the room more closely, searching for other subtle hints that might unravel the enigma before him.

"Holmes, siempre has sido demasiado seguro de ti mismo", comenzó a hablar el profesor, su voz suave pero cargada de una promesa de peligro. La conversación se desvanecía en el viento, dejando atrás una sensación de inevitable confrontación, una que prometía ser la prueba final de la astucia y habilidad de ambos individuos. La noche se adentraba en sus últimas horas, y con ella, la posibilidad de que la historia de Holmes y Moriarty fuera escrita para siempre.

Holmes's brows were drawn down in profound thought, and his usually sharp and observant eyes were dull and listless. Dr. Watson, his companion, sat opposite him, watching his friend with a mixture of concern and curiosity. The detective had been in a peculiar mood all evening, restless and preoccupied, his mind clearly occupied with some intricate problem. Watson knew better than to disturb him when he was in such a state, for Holmes's concentration was legendary, and any interruption could send him into a temporary fit of irritation. The fire crackled and popped, casting flickering shadows across the walls, but Holmes seemed oblivious to the world around him. Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, he raised his head, his eyes regaining their usual sharpness and clarity. "Watson," he said, his voice cutting through the silence like a knife, "I believe I have made a breakthrough in our case. The evidence points to a most unexpected culprit." His words hung in the air, promising a new twist in their ongoing investigation.

"Watson," he began, his voice urgent, "we have a most extraordinary case on our hands. A murder most foul has been committed, and the perpetrator is none other than—" He paused, his gaze darting to the window as if expecting an intruder. "We must act swiftly. The victim was found in the most peculiar circumstances, in the heart of the city, amidst the bustling life of London. The killer's method was both brutal and cunning, leaving behind a trail that only someone with my unique insight could decipher. We have little time, my friend. The killer is likely to strike again, and the next victim could be anyone. We must unravel this mystery before darkness engulfs London once more." He paced the room, his mind clearly racing, formulating the next steps in his mind. "First, we need to examine the crime scene more closely. There are bound to be details overlooked by the police. Then, we shall interview the victim's associates. There is more to this than meets the eye, a hidden agenda, perhaps a secret society. Prepare yourself, Watson, for this is a case that will test our mettle and our wits to the utmost." He stopped pacing, his eyes locking onto mine with a piercing intensity. "Are you ready to accompany me into the heart of this mystery?"

en_results_raw: “Now, Mr. Sherlock Holmes,” said the lady as we entered a well-lit dining-room, upon the table of which a cold supper had been laid. The room was tastefully decorated, with a large bay window overlooking the garden, and the air was filled with the scent of fresh flowers. Holmes took a moment to observe the room, his keen eyes noting the details that others might overlook. The table was set for three, suggesting that we were to dine with another guest. Holmes took a seat, his posture relaxed yet alert, as he awaited the arrival of this mysterious third party. The lady, with a graceful movement, took her place opposite him, her expression a mix of anticipation and a hint of nervousness. “I trust you find everything to your satisfaction,” she said, her voice smooth and controlled. Holmes nodded, his gaze returning to her. “Indeed, it is most accommodating. May I inquire as to the nature of our gathering?” His question hung in the air, a subtle probe into the purpose of this unexpected evening. The lady smiled, a glint of mischief in her eyes. “Ah, Mr. Holmes, that is a tale best told over supper. There are mysteries afoot, and I believe you are just the man to unravel them.” With that enigmatic statement, she gestured to the food, inviting us to begin. The evening promised to be anything but ordinary, and Holmes, ever the detective, was already piecing together the puzzle that lay before him.

en_first_half: “Away we went then, and we drove for at least an hour. Colonel Lysander Stark had said that it was only seven miles, but I should think, from the rate that we seemed to go, and from the time that we took, that it must have been nearer twelve. He sat at my side in silence all the time, and I was aware, more than once when I glanced in his direction, that he was looking at me with great intensity. The country roads seem to be not very good in that part of the world, for we lurched and jolted terribly. I tried to look out of the windows to see something of where we were, but they were made of frosted glass, and I could make out nothing save the occasional bright blur
en_second_half: of a passing light. Now and then I hazarded some remark to break the monotony of the journey, but the colonel answered only in monosyllables, and the conversation soon flagged. At last, however, the bumping of the road was exchanged for the crisp smoothness of a gravel-drive, and the carriage came to a stand. Colonel Lysander Stark sprang out, and, as I followed after him, pulled me swiftly into a porch which gaped in front of us. We stepped, as it were, right out of the carriage and into the hall, so that I failed to catch the most fleeting glance of the front of the house. The instant that I had crossed the threshold the door slammed heavily behind us, and I heard faintly the rattle of the wheels as the carriage drove away.

I found myself wondering about the nature of our mission and why Stark had chosen me to accompany him. Was it my recent service record? My ability to keep a secret? Or was there something more to it?

El coronel Lysander Stark había dicho que sólo eran siete millas, pero yo creía, por la velocidad a la que parecíamos ir, y por el tiempo que tardamos, que debían ser más de doce. Se sentó a mi lado en silencio todo el tiempo, y me di cuenta, más de una vez cuando miré en su dirección, que me estaba mirando con gran intensidad. Parece que las carreteras rurales no son muy buenas en esa parte del mundo, porque dimos unos bandazos y sacudidas terribles. Intenté mirar por las ventanillas para ver algo de dónde estábamos, pero eran de vidrio esmerilado, y no pude distinguir nada más que el borrón ocasional de una luz que pasaba. De vez en
es_second_half: cuando me arriesgaba a hacer algún comentario para romper la monotonía del viaje, pero el coronel sólo respondía con monosílabos, y la conversación pronto decaía. Por fin, sin embargo, los golpes de la carretera fueron sustituidos por la crujiente suavidad de un camino de grava, y el carruaje se detuvo. El coronel Lysander Stark se bajó de él y, mientras yo lo seguía, me arrastró a un porche que se abría ante nosotros. Bajamos, por así decirlo, del carruaje y entramos en el vestíbulo, de modo que no pude echar la más fugaz mirada a la fachada de la casa. En el instante en que crucé el umbral, la puerta se cerró de golpe detrás de nosotros, y oí débilmente el traqueteo de las ruedas mientras el carruaje se alejaba."

en_results_raw: “I find the stories of crime fascinating, as if they are puzzles waiting to be solved. The agony column, on the other hand, offers a glimpse into the private sorrows of others, a reminder that beneath the surface, everyone carries their own burdens. I am particularly drawn to the anonymous letters, where individuals pour out their hearts, seeking solace or advice. It's a curious habit, I know, but it provides a certain comfort, a connection to the world through shared suffering and intrigue. In a way, it mirrors my own life, filled with mysteries and personal struggles that I keep hidden from view. Perhaps, in reading these columns, I find a reflection of my own existence, a silent understanding that I am not alone in my complexities.”
